mxCell.value: Module 2 - Budget Review

<<Budget>>

Here you can see the current month as well as previous and future months.
I clicked calendar #3!

<<Budget>>

Let's say you want to compare several months at once.

Depending on your browser zoom level, you can select up to six months at a time. Please click the third calendar icon.
highlight: calendar_icons

<<Budget>>

Now you can view three months. Let's change the view so you can see a different set of months using the purple selection.
highlight: months_band

<<Budget>>

Below the current month, there are several pieces of information and an amount labeled "To Budget."
highlight: budget_header

<<Budget>>

Please select the purple number, which should have $2,005, to see some options for this amount.

There are multiple ways to move money around your budget. After all, it's meant to be flexible!

<<Budget>>

Let's move on to the Budget Table! This is the table below the Budget Summary where you will budget dollars, update your categories, and adjust your budget table based on your assigned scenario.

<<Budget>>

The budget table is a digital cash envelope system. You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars accordingly. 

As your virtual coach, MyBudgetCoach will automatically build a starting budget table later on in this Module.

<<Budget>>

First up is the Category column. The Category column houses the names of each category.

<<Budget>>

The first column that will have dollar amounts is the Budgeted column. The Budgeted column is where you'll be entering amounts to budget available dollars in advance of your spending.

This is how you create a plan for how you want to use your income prior to spending.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent in a category throughout the month. 

When you categorize a transaction in your Account, that amount is added to the total Spent for that category.

<<Budget>>

To the right of the header 'Category' at the top of the Budget Table, select the three dots. This gives you visual options. You can show and hide hidden categories and collapse or expand categories.

<<Budget>>

The rows that have bold text are called "Category Groups." When you hover to the right of a Category Group name, an arrow appears.

The arrow in a Category Group row has options to add a category, hide that category group, rename that category group, or delete that category group.
Module 1 - Section 3

<<Accounts>>

Select the date section within the blank transaction row and choose today's date.

<<Accounts>>

For the category, select "Bills."

<<Accounts>>

Finish this transaction by selecting the check mark to turn it green.

<<Accounts>>

Notice the account balance is now $1,905, which is $2,005 - $100.
highlight: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

Let's delete the pretend Cell Phone transaction. Go ahead and hover on the left side of the date to un-hide a box. Select the box.

<<Accounts>>

Alright [[user_first_name]], that wraps up Module 1! Excellent work and you are off to a great start.

<<Accounts>>

To the right hand side of the search box, select the purple text with '1 transaction' to see a series of options.

Select 'Delete' to remove the transaction.

Welcome [[user_first_name]] to MyBudgetCoach! MyBudgetCoach is a unique budgeting software that comes along with a virtual avatar. I look forward to helping you start a new phase of your journey to financial wellness!

Please select the purple button below.

<<Accounts>>

There are just a few more functions to point out on the Account screen.

<<Accounts>>

The 'Import' button allows you to upload an export of transactions from your bank.
highlight: import_button

<<Accounts>>

The 'Filter' button allows you to filter down the transactions you are viewing by certain criteria (date, payee, category...).
highlight: filter_button

<<Accounts>>

The 'Undo' and 'Redo' buttons are helpful tools when you are working in this screen.

Please note: These are also available in the Budget screen as well. However, when selected, they will 'Undo' or 'Redo' your last action completed for either Accounts or Budget, depending on where your last action was.

<<Accounts>>

This is the 'Search' bar. As you type, whether text or numbers, the list of transactions will dynamically filter down based on criteria entered.
highlight: search_bar

<<Accounts>>

This is the 'Split/Toggle' button. If you happen to have split transactions, this button will expand or collapse those transactions from view.
highlight: split_toggle_button

<<Accounts>>

These three dots show additional options.

<<Accounts>>

1. Show running balance
2. Hide 'cleared' checkboxes
3. Hide reconciled transactions
4. Export
5. Reconcile
6. Link account
7. Close account

Let me give a quick overview of each of these options.
highlight: more_button

<<Accounts>>

Type "Cell Phone Company" as your Payee and select "+ Create Cell Phone Company" to save the payee.
highlight: select_payee
highlight: select_category

<<Accounts>>

Now, enter $100 in the Payment column of the transaction row.
highlight: payment_input

<<Accounts>>

Now select "Add" to save the transaction and then select "Cancel" to get out of adding transactions.
highlight: cleared_status_icon
highlight: save_transaction
highlight: months_band
highlight: budget_table
highlight: category_column
highlight: budgeted_column
highlight: spent_column
highlight: balance_column

<<Budget>>

The rows without bold text, below a Category Group row, are called Categories.

When you hover to the right of a Category name, the arrow that appears gives you the option to Hide, Rename, and Delete that Category.

<<Budget>>

Also when you hover on a Category row, a small paper icon appears on the right side of the box. Selecting this opens up a note box. This can be used to capture helpful information about that category.

For example, the amount you intend to budget each month or the day of the month your bill is due.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over the month at the top of the budget summary, two up arrows are shown to the left. Selecting this will collapse the budget summary view to only show the 'To Budget' amount.

You can expand by hovering over the month and then selecting the two arrows (now pointing down) to the left of the month.

<<Budget>>

To the right of the name of the month there are three vertical dots. Selecting this shows additional options that can have dollars budgeted to all your categories in one click.

<<Budget>>

These options include:

1. Copy last month's budget
2. Set budgets to zero
3. Set budgets to 3 month average
highlight: budget_more_button
highlight: selected_transactions_button

Module 1 - 
Sections 1 & 2

<<Accounts>>

Module 1 - Account set-up, has three sections:

1. Updating Budget File Name
2. Adding an Account
3. Adding a Transaction

<<Accounts>>

You can set-up multiple budgets in your MyBudgetCoach account. An example for when a new budget can be helpful is when you have a big life event, such as a change in job, and want to start 'fresh' with your new financial reality.

<<Accounts>>

MyBudgetCoach allows you to name each budget. I recommend to name the Budget something specific, and end with "..._MonthYear" that you started the budget. This will help you remember which month the budget file begins with for researching historical time periods.
I updated the name of my budget file

<<Accounts>>

Select your Budget Name in the top left and select 'Rename budget' to update the name. Once you have typed a new name for your budget, select "Enter" to have your budget name updated.
highlight: budget_name
Let's start Section 2 of Module 1

<<Accounts>>

That completes Section 1 of Module 1!

Let's now move to Section 2 of Module 1 - Adding Account.

<<Accounts>>

MyBudgetCoach allows users to add a "Local" account, which is what you will do shortly. 

Local refers to an unlinked account. A linked account is an account that pulls in transactions from your bank. 

You can complete the "Import Transaction Options" conversation to learn more about how to link your account once you have completed the Introduction conversation. Select 'Start a New Conversation' to access this separate conversation.

<<Accounts>>

To start off, we will add just a checking account. 

In your early days of using MyBudgetCoach, I recommend adding just your checking account, and leaving out any savings accounts.

<<Accounts>>

Please select "+ Add Account" in the left menu bar.
highlight: add_account

<<Accounts>>

Great work [[user_first_name]]! You have now completed Section 2 of Module 1. 

Let's move to Section 3 - Adding Transactions, the last section for Module 1.

<<Accounts>>

Now that you have updated your budget file name and added your checking account, let's review how to add a transaction.

<<Accounts>>

As a friendly reminder, don't forget to select the "Back" button if you want to review a step again.

<<Accounts>>

For any account, there are two types of transactions: those that increase the balance, and those that decrease the balance. 

For a checking account, when you get paid by your job, the amount of income will be entered in the "Deposit" column.

<<Accounts>>

Transactions that decrease the balance when you spend money, such as paying rent or buying groceries, will have an amount in the "Payment" column.

<<Accounts>>

Let's review! 

Transactions that INCREASE the balance of your checking account will have an amount in the "Deposit" column and transactions that DECREASE the balance of your checking account will have an amount in the "Payment" column.

<<Accounts>>

Let's now add some hypothetical transactions.

We will start off with adding a paycheck and then later on, pay your cell phone bill.

<<Accounts>>

Select "+ Add New" in the top menu bar and select today's date.
highlight: add_new_button

<<Accounts>>

For the category, select "Income."

To find the "Income" category you can start typing "Inc" and the categories shown will filter down. You can also scroll down to locate the "Income" category.

<<Accounts>>

Type "Job" as your Payee and select "+ Create Payee Job" to save the payee.
highlight: select_payee
highlight: select_category

<<Accounts>>

Finish this transaction by selecting the check mark to turn it green. This action "clears" the transaction.

<<Accounts>>

Notice the account balance went from $5 to $2,005 because you added income from your job as a Deposit.
highlight: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

Now, enter $2,000 in the Deposit column of the transaction row.
highlight: deposit_input

<<Accounts>>

Now select "Add." 

Please note, you can select "Cancel" to get out of adding transactions after we enter the cell phone bill payment.
highlight: cleared_status_icon
highlight: save_transaction

<<Accounts>>

Let's now add a transaction for paying the cell phone bill.

<<Accounts>>

Great work adding those transactions, [[user_first_name]]!

<<Accounts>>

Let me check in to see how you are doing. As a reminder, I will be here and available to pick up where you left off on your schedule.

Let's kick off Module 2 - Budget Review. This module includes the following two sections:

1. Budget Summary Review
2. Budget Table Review
Please navigate from Accounts to the Budget. Please select the Budget section within the left side menu bar.

<<Budget>>

The Budget screen includes two main sections: the Budget Summary and the Budget Table.

Let's start off with the months listed above the Budget Summary section.

<<Budget>>

Before the software automatically creates a starting budget table, let me teach you some additional navigation and editing options for the Budget Table.

<<Budget>>

Great work [[user_first_name]]! You have now completed the review of the software. You have learned about the Accounts throughout Module 1, and just completed the Budget overview within Module 2.
Module 3 - Budget set-up

<<Budget>>

You are now ready to begin Module 3 - Budget Set-Up!

<<Budget>>

That was the last budget table component to review! You now have a starting budget table. A few more things before we wrap-up Module 3.

<<Budget>>

Budgeting is extremely personal and give yourself some grace if the budgeted amount does not turn out to be reality. Those are just starting points for assessing your own spending and planning for the future to meet your goals. You may need to budget more in some categories and less in others, and that is totally fine.

<<Budget>>

The key is to maintain the essential equation of income needs to be greater than or equal to all expenses and saving. Increased spending in one area must come at the expense of another to avoid the need to rely on debt.
highlight: more_button
highlight: budget_header
highlight: budget_table

<<Accounts>>

Now follow these steps:

1. Select "Create local account"

2. Name your account

3. Select a type of "For Budget: Checking" 

4. Enter a starting balance of $5

<<Budget>>

Each envelope is labeled with a purpose. Housing, Food, Utilities, etc. You stuff those envelopes with the money from pay day.

<<Budget>>

When your available dollars in the 'To Budget' has gone to $0, that means no more money is available to go into envelopes. You either have to wait until the next payday, move money from on category to another, or commit to not spend money in that unfunded category.

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. 

If the amount is positive and black, the amount shown is what you have remaining to spend throughout the rest of the month.

If it's negative and red, you've overspent the category.

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover this overspending, you risk over-spending your checking account balance. This is also known as an "overdraft of your account" and banks generally charge a fee when this occurs.

You always want to avoid spending more than you have available. Having a plan for how you will use your income in advance can reduce that risk.

<<Budget>>

Before you continue, please select the left most calendar icon to adjust your view from three months to just one month.
I am ready to continue!

<<Budget>>

I will give you a few minutes to enter in the Note for each category the presumed budgeted amount.

<<Budget>>

Now that you have entered into the Notes the budgeted amount for each category, it is time to budget dollars to each category!
Module 4 - Budgeting Dollars
I have Budgeted all my dollars!

<<Budget>>

When your available dollars in the 'To Budget' have gone to $0, that means no more money is available to go into the categories. You will need to move money from one category to another.

<<Budget>>

You are only going to budget the dollars you have available in your account. The goal is to budget an amount in every category.

<<Budget>>

There are multiple ways you can budget dollars into a category:

1. Type in an amount into the Budgeted column and select Enter.
2. Select the 'To Budget' number and enter in the amount you want to move to a category.

<<Budget>>

Keep in mind you can hover over the Note to find the amounts for each category you previously entered.

<<Budget>>

There is just one more category to add. Instead of the software adding it for you, you will add this category!

Let's call the category "❓Misc."

<<Budget>>

This category is for the things you forgot about or come up unexpectedly. You should budget a small amount of money in this category such as $50-$100 when you allocate your money and then pay for those unexpected expenses from this category.

<<Budget>>

Fantastic work [[user_first_name]]!

Remember that your budgeted amount will be fluid and will change throughout the month as you experience unexpected expenses. That is OK!

<<Budget>>

Budgeted amounts are meant to be flexible, reviewed on a recurring basis, and you should feel free to edit and change based on what is happening each month.

Please keep in mind that when you categorize transactions in an account screen, the expenses incurred for that category will be totaled in the 'Spent' column and you will use the Balance column (Budgeted - Spent) to determine how many dollars remain in your budget.

<<Budget>>

If your 'To Budget' number becomes a negative red, that means you have over budgeted dollars. You have budgeted more dollars than you have available.

You need to adjust your Budgeted columns to get back to $0 or a positive purple number. We don't want to Budget dollars we don't have!
highlight: calendar_icons
highlight: budget_more_button

<<Budget>>

To add a new category, hover to the right of Flexible within the Category Group row, and select the arrow that appears.

Select the "Add category" option. Within the newly created category field, copy and paste "❓ Misc." as the category name.

<<Budget>>

Once you have added this category, drag and drop the category to be the last category in the Flexible section, and enter the $50-$100 into the Note.

Once completed, select the "Next" button below.

<<Budget>>

Now, please type in the Note for each category the proposed amount you believe will be spent for each category.

Let's move over to your Checking Account, and update the amount of your income from the $2,000 we originally entered, to your actual monthly net income.

If you don't know the exact amount, use an approximation just for learning purposes.

<<Accounts>>

Please update the amount in the Deposit column of the Income transaction from $2,000 to the amount of your actual monthly net income.
Let's now go back to the Budget.

<<Budget>>

Your 'To Budget' number in purple at to the top of the Budget Table should now be your entered monthly net income + $5.

<<Budget>>

If you need additional categories for different items that don't fit in these broad ones, then just add a new category like you did for '❓ Misc.'
Let me start off introducing myself. I am a personal financial counselor and I work for Zeiders Enterprises. I was selected as your coach based on the attributes you selected at the time of sign-up.
Zeiders is a veteran-owned company with over four decades of experience providing human services solutions. As a financial counselor with Zeiders, I am a credentialed counselor.

I also completed a comprehensive training program to become MyBudgetCoach certified. I am an expert on the software and I am available to answer any questions you may have. 

There are three different ways you can work with me to learn the software and grow your financial wellness.

The first is by completing this virtual conversation. Please complete the steps as instructed. Users who complete the entire Introduction conversation have a much higher success rate using the software.

The second is to send me a secure message within the Message Center. The Message Center is accessed by selecting the "Messages" section on the left side menu bar under the "Schedules" option. 

I will reply to a question you send within two business days or less.

Once I send you a response, if you happen to not view the message in MyBudgetCoach within 15 minutes, the software will automatically send you a courtesy email with a short preview of my response. 

Please log back in to MyBudgetCoach to reply and ask any additional questions.

The third way is to book a one-on-one video call with me. This is an additional cost, separate from the software subscription, and is billed separately. These one hour meetings are paid for in advance.
highlight: zoom_link

Unlike a traditional financial counser, I don't require you pay for a number of sessions upfront. As a user with MyBudgetCoach, you can decide how often you would like to meet. 

Generally, clients meet a few times early on, and then once they have become a routine user, meetings occur sporadically.

As mentioned earlier, by completing the Introduction conversation, you are maximizing the value of this walk-through at no additional cost. If you decide to book a one-hour video session and have completed this Introduction conversation, I can maximize your time and money invested.
highlight: zoom_link
highlight: zoom_link
Can we programmatically reference the coach name and attributes, such as tenure and experience?

To book a 1:1 call, please select the "Schedule Video Call" button outlined in yellow within the left hand menu bar. Once selected, you will be brought to my calendar booking page and you can select a time that works best for you.
highlight: zoom_link

As your virtual coach, I am available whenever you are. You can complete this conversation all at once, or you can complete it over time. Please move at your pace, and whenever you are ready for the next step of our work together, I will be here to help you out.

If you want to review a step again, select the 'Back' button below. 

If you want to hide the avatar conversation, select the 'x' at the top left of my picture. You can continue the conversation by selecting the 'Introduction' conversation in the left side menu bar above the 'Schedule Video Call' button.

In the bottom right of this conversation window, there are three vertical dots. This gives you the options to:

1) Give Feedback
2) Reset This Conversation
3) End This Conversation
[[user_first_name]], there may be times in the modules that I ask you to enter something into a blank box. Please enter your response so the software can use your answer in the future.
Now that I have introduced myself and the software, I want to learn more about you!

Active Duty
military_status = active_duty

Never Served
military_status = none

Serving in Guard or Reserves
military_status = guard_reserves

Spouse of Military Member
military_status = spouse
Which of the following options best describes your current military status?

Thank you for your commitment to serving our country.

In future modules of the conversation, I will tailor my advice based on your military status.

I understand the unique budgeting scenarios for members of the military.

Thank you for your response.

I undertand the unique budgeting scenarios for spouses of military members.
Thank you for your response!
I am not familiar what you are referring to.
I am aware of those services, but I want to use MyBudgetCoach and work with you as my financial counselor instead.

When you signed up, you were disclosed the fact that you are eligible for free financial counseling services through a program funded by the Department of Defense.

Please confirm you are aware of these services available to you.
No thanks; I will research those resources instead.

Understood! The following is a link to a website with additional information on the free services that are available.

<insert link to resources>

Would you like to continue using MyBudgetCoach?

Thank you for confirming you are aware of those services.

Let's continue!

I completely understand and I wish you all the best as you pursue your financial wellness journey elsewhere!

If at a later point you are interested in exploring this software again, feel free to sign-up for a free trial to get started.

Once you select "Good-bye!" this conversation will end.
Nope! Just me
Are you budgeting with a partner?
Before we dive in, let me start off with a question.
Thanks for sharing!

Next
partner_name = [user_input]
Sounds good! Please share with me their first name.
Ok great [[user_first_name]]! I look forward to helping you and [[partner_name]] improve your financial wellness.

Please keep in mind there are more conversations, in addition to the Introduction conversation, to support your long-term use of the software.

Once you complete this Introduction conversation, select "Start a New Conversation" above the 'Schedule Video Call' button to review the additional conversations available.

If you are seeking support, make sure to review those available conversations first. They are available to you at no additional cost as part of the software subscription. If after completing a conversation you still have questions on a topic, feel free to book a call with me and I will be happy to help.

Now that you have completed the overview portion, let's kick-off the first module, Module 1 - Account set-up!

There are a total of four modules in this Introduction conversation.

<<Accounts>>

For this tutorial, we are going to start off with a $5 balance for your checking account. This will be updated prior to ending the conversation.

<<Accounts>>

Show Running Balance: This is an additional column that shows the balance after each transaction. This is very helpful during reconciliation. Please select this now to turn on for your checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Hide cleared checkboxes: This removes the column showing the cleared (green) or uncleared (grey) checkbox.

<<Accounts>>

Export: You can download transactions as a csv file.

<<Accounts>>

Reconcile: This is a very important feature. Reconciliation is the process to verify the account balance and transactions in MyBudgetCoach match your bank account.

<<Accounts>>

In the future, please select the 'Reconciliation Step by Step' conversation within the listed conversations after selecting 'Start a New Conversation' if you have any questions on how to reconcile your accounts.

<<Accounts>>

Link account: This option allows the user to link MyBudgetCoach to their bank to automate adding transactions.

<<Accounts>>

In the future, please select the 'Import Transaction Options' conversation within the listed conversations after selecting 'Start a New Conversation' to learn more about how to link your accounts.

<<Accounts>>

Close account: This is how you close the account you selected to view. You don't need to select this option unless you stop using an account or don't want the account in the budget anymore.

<<Accounts>>

Hide reconciled transactions: When you complete the reconciliation process, the "✅" icon changes to a lock symbol. This option allows you to view only those transactions that haven't been reconciled.
Yup; I will pick up with you next time!

<<Accounts>>

Would you like to
take a break?

<<Accounts>>

I completely understand! Good-bye for now, and when you return, just select 'Next' to continue to Module 2 - Budget Review.
Nope; Let's keep rolling!

<<Accounts>>

Ok! Let's continue to Module 2 - Budget Review.
military_status = active_duty
military_status = guard_reserves
military_status = spouse
military_status = none

<<Budget>>

One of the first questions I asked you was regarding your military status. I will now use your previous response to tailor your budget table set-up.

<<Budget>>

The software will automatically build a starting budget table for you. Once created, I will then explain how easily you can edit and adjust your table to align with your spending plan.

<<Budget>>

Since you are serving in active duty military, there are particular categories of your budget I will include for your consideration.

Let me first ask you a question about where you are stationed.

<<Budget>>

Are you stationed in a foreign country?

Next
foreign_country = [user_input]

<<Budget>>

Please enter the country you are stationed in within the blank box below.

<<Budget>>

Thanks for sharing you are stationed in [[foreign_country]]. I will include a category group for these expenses. Please take some time adding specific expenses that are applicable while living in [[foreign_country]].
Show me my new budget...

<<Budget>>

It is now time for the software to build your starting budget table!

<<Budget>>

Here it is! Remember, this is just a starting point. I anticipate you to rename categories, add new categories, and remove some cateogries, provided they aren't applicable.

delete_category_group: Investments and Savings
create_category_group: Fixed

Show me my new budget...

<<Budget>>

It is now time for the software to build your starting budget table.

<<Budget>>

Here it is! Remember, this is just a starting point. I anticipate you to rename categories, add new categories, and remove some cateogries, provided they aren't applicable.

delete_category_group: Usual Expenses
delete_category_group: Investments and Savings
create_category_group: Fixed
create_category: Fixed: 🏡 Housing
create_category: Fixed: ⚡Utilities
create_category: Fixed: 📱Cell Phone
create_category: Fixed: 💻Internet/Cable

create_category: Flexible: 🛒Shopping

create_category: Flexible: 😷Medical

create_category_group: Subscriptions

<<Budget>>

Thanks for your response!

Phase 2:

Within Income - stipen versus paycheck so can see if housing expenses are in excess or less than housing stipen.

<<Budget>>

You previously answered you are serving in the military guard or reserves.

<<Budget>>

You previously answered you are a spouse of a member of the military.

<<Budget>>

Are you living in a foreign country?

Next
foreign_country = [user_input]

<<Budget>>

Please enter the country you are living within the blank box below.

<<Budget>>

Thanks for your response!

<<Budget>>

Thanks for sharing you are living in [[foreign_country]]. I will include an entire category group for these expenses. Please take some time adding specific expenses that are applicable while living in [[foreign_country]].
Fixed = Due on the same day each month

<<Budget>>

The 'Fixed' Category Group will include Categories that have expenses which are generally the same amount and paid on the same day each month. For example, a rent or mortgage, a car payment, cell phone...
Fixed = Fund first!

<<Budget>>

When analyzing your budget, the 'Fixed' group of expenses can be viewed as necessities and where your money needs to go first. You have to make sure you have money available for your car payment prior the payment date.
Flexible = Variable timing and amount

<<Budget>>

Separately, Flexible expenses are things required to live: groceries; gas for the car; clothing; but the same amount and timing are not consistent each month. These categories are those that you would want to analyze if you are looking to reduce spending resulting in left over income for savings or funding a future months' expenses.

<<Budget>>

Let's review some details of the budget table that has been created for you.

<<Budget>>

Non-Monthly can be used for expenses paid on a quarterly, twice a year, or annual basis. For example, Car Maintenance or Gifts for the yearly Holiday Season.

<<Budget>>

As your coach, I recommend you set aside an amount each month to these Categories. Overtime, the amount in your Balance will accumulate and be available for use when the expense does come up.

<<Budget>>

For the Goals Category Group, you could include items/experiences that take time to save for, such as a New Laptop.

<<Budget>>

The Categories in the Goals Category Group should also have dollars assigned each month. When that vacation comes up, you can leave your home stress-free knowing you have an amount of money set aside to reduce stress spending money while on vacation!

<<Budget>>

A few other organizational recommendations.

<<Budget>>

Consider adding the day of the month to the Note for each category in the Fixed category group. Then you can organize the Categories in chronological order to prioritize the use of your available money based on where you are in the month.

Remember, fund the expenses due prior to the next time you receive income.

<<Budget>>

Also, consider adding the amount you expect to spend to the Note for each category in the Flexible category group. For example, $100 for Clothing. Adding the amount you expect to spend to a Note you can hover over will help you compare your actual spending to the amount you expect.

<<Budget>>

If after your first full month of MyBudgetCoach use, your proposed amount is far off from the actual spent, you know you either need to change your spending behavior, or change the proposed amount for your budget.

<<Budget>>

Adding an amount to a Note for each Flexible Category Name creates the ability for you to total up your proposed amounts across your Categories and compare that to your Income - Fixed Expenses - Flexible Expenses. If the result is negative, you know it is highly unlikely you will have savings available at the end of each month.

<<Budget>>

You can also add the total of your Categories to the name of your Category Group. This is a quick way of looking at your overall spending on any one day of the month compared to the total anticipated, without analyzing each Category individually.

<<Budget>>

For example, if you are half-way through the month, but have spent 75% of your Flexible total proposed amount, you should analyze further what adjustments need to be made for the second half of the month to either remain within the proposed amount, or find more dollars to increase the Balance available.

<<Budget>>

Think of MyBudgetCoach as creating a series of digital envelopes to store your money. Each envelope has a specific purpose and creates intentionality in your cash flow management.

<<Budget>>

Great job setting up your budget table!

<<Budget>>

Below the categories is the 'Income' Section.

<<Budget>>

The Income row is the total amount of deposits to a checking or savings account in a month.

The Starting Balances row is calculated your first month, but then remains $0 each month after that.

Ok! Let's continue to Module 4 - Budgeting Dollars.
Let me ask, do you routinely use credit cards for spending?
When you are done with this conversation, please select the 'Add Credit Card' conversation from the list of available conversations under 'Start a New Conversation.'

For this last module, Module 4 - Budgeting Dollars, we will be creating a hypothetical budget, prior to you using the software and adding real transactions. This will give you practice for how to budget dollars and give you an understanding on how to assign dollars in advance of spending.
You can select 'Reset Coach' in the 'Manage Coach' menu to the left and navigate back through from the beginning of the tutorial to any section you want to cover again.

If while using the system, you have a question that you come across, feel free to send me a message in the 'Messages' section below the 'Schedules' option within the menu bar on the left. I will review and reply within two business days or less.
If after reviewing your inquiry I determine it would be best to have a 1:1 call, I will recommend you schedule a one-hour session with me through the MyBudgetCoach platform.
To pay for a one-on-one session, I will send you an invoice to your email on-file that was used when you book the call. I ask that payment is completed prior to the scheduled session.
KUDOS on taking action and completing this tutorial of the MyBudgetCoach software. Contact me if you have any questions in the future and have a great rest of your day!

Thanks for selecting the Add Credit Card conversation!

This conversation walks through the steps for how to add a credit card account. Whether you are new MyBudgetCoach user, or a long-term user that now needs to add a credit card account, this conversation is meant for you.

<<Accounts>>

Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance.
highlight: zoom_link

<<Accounts>>

Before we link a third credit card account, let me ask a follow-up question.
highlight: add_account

<<Budget>>

Because you can pay the balance in-full and have a credit card category with a 'Balance' = 0, moving forward with your MyBudgetCoach use, you will be funding your categories outside of the credit card category. If you aren't accumulating any debt, have covered any overspent categories, then your credit card payment will be equal to the current balance of your credit card.
highlight: add_account

For the credit card account(s) you added, are there any that you plan to pay off the current balance at the end of this month?

Please note, by 'current balance' I am referring to the balance you entered when you added the account. This is not the statement balance, which is a balance as of an earlier date.
You can complete the 'Calculate Credit Card Payment' conversation at any time to assist in determining what your credit card payment should be.

<<Accounts>>

Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance.

<<Budget>>

Give yourself some grace and remember, reducing your debt is a journey and takes dedication. You already have started working toward your goal by using this budgeting software and working through this conversation to learn more!

<<Budget>>

If you have more than one credit card account, you will need to complete the following steps for each account.

<<Budget>>

Step 1 is to create a Category Group called 'Credit Cards.' Under that Category Group, you would add a Category for each of the credit card account(s) you added.

Let me add this for you as a starting point...

<<Budget>>

OK! Step 1 is completed. Please scroll down to the bottom of your budget table to find the Credit Card category group and rename the newly created category to your specific credit card account name.

create_category_group: Credit Cards
create_category: Credit Cards: Credit Card Account

<<Accounts>>

The first transaction should be the transaction that was added when you first added the account. You should see an amount in the 'Payment' column that equals the balance on the day you added the account.

<<Accounts>>

Now that we have created the category on the Budget for the Credit Card Account, we are going to change the Category from 'Starting Balance' to the newly created category for your Credit Card Account.
Great work! Now, lets go back to the Budget and see what happened with the 'Spent' and 'Balance' columns in the Credit Card Account category.

<<Budget>>

Scroll down to the credit card category of the account you just updated. Now the 'Spent' column is a negative number that equals your balance you entered previously.

<<Budget>>

Since the 'Budgeted' column for the category is 0, the 'Balance' is a negative red number and is equal to 'Spent.'
highlight: spent_column

<<Budget>>

The last step, Step 3, is to complete the actions for how you want MyBudgetCoach to handle the debt associated with the credit card. You have some options, so let me first ask you a question so I can tailor my guidance.

<<Budget>>

Good for you! KUDOS on managing your debt. Very few people with a credit card balance have the cash flow to pay in-full at any time.

<<Budget>>

To fund your balance enter the amount in the 'Spent' column, the Starting Balance of your credit card, in the 'Budgeted' column of your newly created credit card category. This will update the 'Balance' to be 0 since you budgeted dollars to equal the current balance of the credit card.

<<Budget>>

When you Budgeted the dollars, the purple number at the top of the Budget Summary in the 'To Budget' went down.

<<Budget>>

You can now budget with confidence the rest of your available dollars to your remaining categories, until your 'To Budget' number is 0. If you would like to learn more about this process, select the 'Make To Budget Equal to 0' conversation to work through that conversation when you have completed this conversation.

<<Budget>>

We need to allow the remaining balance you don't pay off this current month, to continue to future months, since your credit card company will continue to have that balance carry over until you pay it off.

<<Budget>>

MyBudgetCoach has a unique feature that is called 'Rollover overspending.' This option allows a user to have the debt continue into future months, instead of paying off this month, so you can pay it off overtime.

<<Budget>>

Selecting the 'Rollover overspending' option increases your 'To Budget' number in the current month, since the debt has now been rolled over to future months.

<<Budget>>

Select the negative amount in red text in the Balance column of your Credit Card Account Category. Within the option menu that comes up, select the 'Rollover overspending' option.

To see the system roll the debt over to a future month, select the option in the top left to show two months at a time by selecting the 2nd calendar icon.

<<Budget>>

The arrow to the right of the amount in the Balance column is how MyBudgetCoach alerts you to the fact you have rolled over the overspending for future months. This option will stay turned on for all future months, unless you select to 'Remove overspending rollover.'

<<Budget>>

When you budget to the category it reduces the debt immediately. You'll still have to submit a payment through your credit card account, but you can see your progress in the category right away.

<<Budget>>

To handle interest applied to your credit card account(s), if applicable, you would categorize that transaction to the Category of your Credit Card Account, just like how you updated the Starting Balance category.

<<Budget>>

Credit Cards can be complex, especially if you have more than one credit card account. I am available for a one-on-one call at your convenience to help answer any questions you may have in your future use of MyBudgetCoach.

<<Accounts>>

The important difference between a bank account and a credit card account is that for a credit card account, Payments INCREASE the balance, and Deposits DECREASE the balance. This is because a credit card balance is negative.

<<Accounts>>

Please select your main credit card account. You will now add two hypothetical transactions.

<<Accounts>>

Please select '+ Add New,' select today's date and enter a Payee of 'Cell Phone Company.'

<<Accounts>>

Select an applicable category and enter a Payment amount of 100, Clear the transaction, and select Add.

<<Accounts>>

Let's now add a transaction for a credit card payment. Credit Card payments are Transfers and entered as a Deposit.

<<Accounts>>

The credit card balance, a red negative number, has now increased by 100.

<<Accounts>>

Please select '+ Add New,' select today's date, and for the Payee, select 'Make Transfer.' Within the 'Transfer To/From' list of accounts, select your checking account.

<<Accounts>>

The Category field is now populated with Transfer. Enter 100 in the 'Deposit' field, since this is a payment to reduce the credit card balance, and select Add.

<<Accounts>>

Let's now jump over to the checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Since you selected 'Make Transfer' as the Payee in your credit card account, this automatically added a transaction to your checking account as well.

<<Accounts>>

Please take note that the credit card payment is an outflow in the Payment column for the checking account, but an inflow in the Deposit column for the credit card. This is because your payment reduces a negative balance (Deposit) in the credit card account and reduces the positive balance (Payment) in the checking account.

<<Accounts>>

KUDOS on creating transactions for both accounts!

<<Accounts>>

Before we move to the next step, let's delete those two credit card transactions you added.

<<Accounts>>

Please navigate back to your main credit card account and select each of the two transactions using the box to the left of the date. Then select the link named '2 transactions' to the right of the search bar and choose Delete.

1. Adding Credit Card Account(s)
2. Adding Credit Card transactions
3. Updating Budget Table based on pay off plan
4. Determining your current debt management strategy

Thanks for your help!
Great work setting up your Credit Card accounts in MyBudgetCoach! This ends this conversation. Bye for now...

<<Accounts>>

Which Option would you like to learn more about?
SIMPLE FIN
Direct Import
Bulk Import

<<Accounts>>

Thanks for that information. Direct Import within MyBudgetCoach has some great benefits. For example, the starting balance for linked accounts is automatically set and the system includes three prior days worth of transactions to get you started.

<<Accounts>>

Direct Import removes the additional tasks of having to manually upload transactions. Each time you log in, the system will automatically have added recent transactions.

<<Accounts>>

MyBudgetCoach uses machine learning, so as you continue to use the system, the system will automatically apply proposed categories to new transactions and the manual steps to categorize transactions will lessen over time.

<<Accounts>>

To increase your security, MyBudgetCoach has partnered with a third-party service, SimpleFIN, to link your accounts. SimpleFIN uses a well-established connection software called 'MX' to connect your bank account financial institutions to SimpleFIN.

<<Accounts>>

To connect SimpleFIN to MyBudgetCoach, there is a one-time code produced by SimpleFIN to enter into MyBudgetCoach. The accounts you link in SimpleFIN will then become available to link to already existing accounts within MyBudgetCoach to start Direct Import.

<<Accounts>>

Please note SimpleFIN does have a small additional fee: $1.50 per month, or $15 per year (not including tax, if applicable). This is paid separately from your MyBudgetCoach subscription and is paid through SimpleFIN, not within MyBudgetCoach.
I'm good, thanks!

<<Accounts>>

The Bulk Import process requires you to export/download transactions from your financial institution in a 'csv' file format.
Have you completed an export of transactions from a bank or credit card account before?

<<Accounts>>

Understood! I think it would be best to talk through this further during a one-on-one call with me. I would be happy to walk you through the steps to complete the export of transactions and how to load them to MyBudgetCoach.
Ok great! Are you familiar with how to edit column headings and re-arrange amounts in columns within Excel?

<<Accounts>>

Be sure your columns are organized in the following order:

Date / Payee / Notes / Category (blank) / Amount

The amount can either be one column, or split into separate columns, one for Payments and one for Deposits.

MyBudgetCoach can also split up the amount column into two separate columns by splitting the positive and negative values.

<<Accounts>>

Once you have your data organized the correct way, use the 'Import' button to select your csv file to upload. Follow along the MyBudgetCoach screen to select the appropriate column in your csv file to map to the correct MyBudgetCoach field.

<<Accounts>>

Great job importing your transactions! You can complete these steps at your chosen frequency. I recommend at least once a week until you become comfortable with the software.
Bulk Import

Thanks for selecting the Import Transaction Options conversation!

In this conversation, we will walk through the different methods for adding transactions within MyBudgetCoach.

There are three options:

Option 1: Adding transactions manually (the Introduction conversation walked through this process),

Option 2: Direct Import - using a third-party bank connection software, SimpleFIN. Once completed, when you select 'Sync' transactions will automatically be brought into MyBudgetCoach for all accounts.

Option 3: Bulk Import - uploading exports of transactions from your bank to MyBudgetCoach to add transactions in bulk for each account.

I'm confident I will help you export and upload your transactions.

Thanks for selecting the Make To Budget Equal to 0 conversation!

When in your Budget, the 'To Budget' number is critical to monitor. If it is positive, you have dollars left that need a job in the current month. If it is negative, you over budgeted, and need to take money back. If it is 0, you have successfully balanced your budget. This conversation will provide guidance for how to update the 'To Budget' amount.

<<Budget>>

Please review the 'Balance' amount in your non-Credit Card categories. If the 'Balance' is greater than 0, consider whether the amount you entered in the Budget column is required now prior to receiving your next source of income.

<<Budget>>

You can move money between categories, or back to the 'To Budget' number, by selecting the amount in the 'Balance' column. Please be sure you maintain enough money in the 'Balance' for categories that have future expenses due to be paid from your checking account.

When you have moved your available money, come back to continue.
No; It remains a negative red number

How are you adding transactions in your MyBudgetCoach accounts?
Ok! Wait a few days for the payment to be posted to your credit card and bank accounts.
You may need to categorize the transaction as a 'Transfer' if MyBudgetCoach doesn't do this automatically.

<<Accounts>>

When reviewing your Credit Card account transactions, locate (or add) the row for the payment and adjust the Payee by selecting 'Make Transfer.' Within the 'Transfer To/From' list of accounts, select your checking account.

<<Accounts>>

The Category field is now populated with Transfer. The amount in the 'Deposit' column, equal to the payment amount, reduces the credit card balance. Select Add.

<<Accounts>>

Let's now jump over to the checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Since you selected 'Make Transfer' as the Payee in your credit card account, this automatically added a transaction to your checking account as well. Double check if a duplicate Payment transaction exists on your account. If there is one, delete it so the transaction with the 'Transfer' is the only payment transaction.

<<Accounts>>

Please take note that the 'Payment' field is populated for the checking account, which reduces the balance. However, the credit card account has the Deposit field populated because an inflow to a negative balance reduces the negative balance.
Yes; I have completed this before
Do you know how to categorize a payment to a credit card as a 'Transfer?'
No; Could you please review?
Thanks for your help!

You have completed the steps for making a payment on your credit card!

Please continue to use this conversation each time you would like help calculating a credit card payment.
Do you have another credit card account you want to calculate the payment for?
Calculating Payment
Recording Payment in MBC
I manually add transactions or Import them
Thanks for entering those numbers!
Great job making a payment and reducing your debt! Let's now walk through how to record that payment in MyBudgetCoach.

<<Budget>>

Let's start off with you sharing what your Budget has for today's present month.

Is your 'To Budget' number = 0?
To Budget = 0
No or Not sure; Any suggestions?
Have you funded your categories that will have expenses prior to receiving your next paycheck?

<<Budget>>

Is your 'To Budget' number for future month(s) equal to 0?

<<Budget>>

Prior to completing this conversation for calculating your credit card payment, please have your 'To Budget' amount in the present month, and future month(s) be equal to 0.
Any suggestions for how to update this?
Start the Make To Budget Equal to 0 conversation

Yes! The 'Make To Budget Equal to 0' conversation has a step-by-step process for how to update your To Budget number. 

Please complete that conversation first, and then select this conversation, Calculate Credit Card Payment, to start from the beginning.
No or Not sure; Any suggestions?

<<Budget>>

Please navigate to a category with a negative red 'Balance.'

Is there a number in the 'Budgeted' column for this category?

<<Budget>>

In this instance, you have spent more than you budgeted for. Since you already have budgeted all dollars, please review your categories that have a positive amount in the Balance column.

<<Budget>>

Is there a category that has a positive number in 'Balance' that isn't expected to be paid out of your checking account prior to you being paid again?

<<Budget>>

To move these dollars to another category, you can either reduce the amount entered in the Budgeted column of that same category, or you can select the amount in the Balance and choose 'Transfer to another category.' Once selected, you can then choose the category with the negative red balance and enter the amount you want to transfer.

<<Budget>>

In this case, please book a video call so I can give you support before making a credit card payment.
Ok; I just booked a video call
I'm confident I can help you resolve your questions and get you back on track.

<<Budget>>

Once your category has been funded, the amount in the Balance column is either equal to 0 or positive, continue a similar process for the rest of your overspent categories.

<<Budget>>

In this instance, you have spent money for a category that hasn't been funded at all. Please review your categories that have a positive amount in the Balance column.

Once your payment has been cleared at your bank, credit card, and recorded in MyBudgetCoach, please review the comparison of your current balance of your credit card account to the Balance in your credit card category. Depending on how many transactions occurred since your payment, they should be close.
If the two numbers are far off, or the credit card category Balance amount is a higher negative number than the current balance of your credit card account, please book a video call with me.
calculate_new_variable: credit_card_payment = credit_card_balance - balance_credit_card_category
credit_card_payment < 0
credit_card_payment > 0
Hmm...it seems you have a result that is negative. Please double check your numbers and enter the information again. Let's go back to an earlier step to try again.
I'm confident I will help resolve your questions and get you back on track.
The software has completed the calculation of the credit card payment for you.

<<Budget>>

I will now loop you back to an earlier part of the conversation so you can work through the particulars for each category that is overspent.
How do I find that conversation?

Select the 'Start the Make To Budget Equal to 0 conversation' button below. This will automatically close this conversation, and bring you to the 'Add Credit Card' conversation automatically.

You can tell which conversation you are currently working through by reviewing the open conversations on the left hand menu and finding the words under the title of the conversation.

If you see the words 'In progress...' this is the conversation you are currently working through. If you see the words 'Continue conversation...' this is a conversation you have started, but not yet completed.

If you are trying to re-start a conversation, please select the three vertical dots in the bottom right and select the 'Reset This Conversation' option.
Ok; I just booked a video call
At this time, it doesn't appear that you have available dollars to make a credit card payment. If you think this is in error, please book a video call with me so I can help review your budget.
highlight: zoom_link
Step 2 Completed!
Please pick a credit card account, and enter your current credit card balance as a positive number. The current balance can be found on the left hand side next to the account name.
You need some help reconciling? No problem. I got you.

<<Accounts>>

The first thing you need to do is figure out what your target balance is. By that I mean, what is the balance in real life that we are matching your MBC account to.
I'm in

<<Accounts>>

Log in to your account in real life.
I'm confident I see it

<<Accounts>>

Ok, you are looking for the most recent "cleared balance." That's the balance that does not include the pending charges. It might also be called the "current balance" or the "posted balance."

Next
balance = [user_input]

<<Accounts>>

Great work. Now we will tell MBC what your current balance is.

If you are reconciling a credit card account, please enter the balance as a negative number.
Ok, I got it

<<Accounts>>

For me, the easiest place to find the balance we need is in the list of recent transactions. Typically there's a section of pending transactions and below that there's all the cleared transactions. Often beside each cleared transaction it'll show the balance after those transactions. Or sometimes it shows it above each day's list of transactions.
Got it

<<Accounts>>

Since it's a credit card account almost always the pending transactions aren't included in the main balance that is displayed. So you can use that most prominently displayed balance.
Find the cleared balance
highlight: more_button
I did that and now there's a box that says "your cleared balance...
I did that and now it says "all reconciled"

<<Accounts>>

Click the more button and then "Reconcile" in the account you're working on.

Enter [[balance]] in the box and press reconcile.

<<Accounts>>

Ok, so currently your MBC account and your real life account don't match, so let's figure out why.
See you next time
I need to reconcile another account

<<Accounts>>

The number you entered matched your MBC account. Awesome. Click "Done Reconciling" and celebrate.

<<Accounts>>

Click here to show the cleared/uncleared totals for your account balance. We want to be able to see those numbers.
"All reconciled!"
Your cleared balance...

<<Accounts>>

Now that everything is marked as cleared that should be, look at the reconciliation dialog. What does it say?
I'm all done now
I need to reconcile another account
I'll book a call
I'd like to give it a try.

<<Accounts>>

At this point you'll need to look for missing, duplicated, mis-typed or otherwise incorrect transactions. I can walk you through some things to look for or you can book a call with me and we can tackle this together.
See you soon

<<Accounts>>

Great, I'll see you soon. In the meantime keep up with entering and categorizing transactions.

<<Accounts>>

Ok, start from the date you last reconciled. You can tell because the cleared/uncleared icon will be a green lock for reconciled transactions.
highlight: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

Cleared balance represents cleared transactions and uncleared are pending transactions. When we reconcile we are only concerned with cleared transactions, since pending ones can change.

<<Accounts>>

If you look in the far right column,  you'll see little buttons beside each transaction. These indicate if the transaction has cleared the bank (green) or not (grey).
highlight: cleared_status_icon

<<Accounts>>

If you enter transactions manually then you also have to click these buttons when you notice a charge has cleared. If you use import you won't have to click them most of the time but might need to mange a few recent ones when you reconcile.
Click the button
Troubleshoot: uncleared

<<Accounts>>

Go ahead and turn these icons green for anything that is no longer pending in real life, leave them grey if they are still pending. As you do that you should see the cleared balance at the top of the screen change, and you'll also see the dialog about reconciling change as well.
highlight: zoom_link

<<Accounts>>

Find that date in your bank as well as your budget account. Look at your bank and go in the order of the transactions there. Check for each one in your budget and check them off (far left of each transaction) as you find them.

<<Accounts>>

Add any transactions that were missed and delete any that are extras. Fix typos if you find them. Also make sure outflows are in the payment column and inflows in the deposit column.

<<Accounts>>

As you go along you can sometimes check the balance at the end of each day against the balance in real life at the end of that day. This will only work if your dates match for each transaction though.
I'm making progress
It's confusing

<<Accounts>>

How's this working so far?

<<Accounts>>

Great, keep it up until you get to the current date.
Yes, I'm doing that now

<<Accounts>>

I get that. It can be a tricky skill to learn. Would you like to book a call?
It sure does
Still no

<<Accounts>>

Look at the reconciliation dialog. Does the reconciliation dialog say "All reconciled!" now?
I'm all done now
I need to reconcile another account
Yes please

<<Accounts>>

There is an option to let the program adjust the balance instead of finding the error. Shall we go ahead and do that?
Is there another option?
Troubleshoot: line by line
highlight: zoom_link
Thanks for your help.

<<Accounts>>

In your reconciliation dialog box there should be a button that says "create reconcilation transaction." Go ahead and click that. Then click "Done Reconciling."

Credit card account
which_account = credit

Bank account
which_account = bank

<<Accounts>>

Will you be reconciling a credit card account or a bank account?
which_account = bank
which_account = credit
I'm unsure if I'm looking at the right place

<<Accounts>>

Thanks! I ask because different types of accounts show balances differently.

<<Accounts>>

It could also be possible that there is a transaction in your bank account, that you don't see in MyBudgetCoach, pending or cleared. In this case, manually add that transaction(s) to ensure all the transactions that are cleared are included in MyBudgetCoach.
highlight: cleared_status_icon

<<Accounts>>

You're now all set to move forward. Be sure to reconcile often moving forward, 2-3 times per week, and hopefully you'll be able to find errors and not have to make adjustments.
